articles.title: Prehistoric crayons provide clues to how Neanderthals created art
articles.summary: Ochre artefacts found in Crimea show signs of having been used for drawing, adding to evidence that Neanderthals used pigments in symbolic ways
articles.content:
Ochre artefacts found in Crimea show signs of having been used for drawing, adding to evidence that Neanderthals used pigments in symbolic ways

Neanderthals may have used ochre crayons to draw on cave walls Gorodenkoff/Getty Images

A remarkable yellow crayon unearthed in Crimea, still sharp after more than 40,000 years, indicates that painting lines on objects was part of Neanderthal culture. This discovery is the firmest evidence yet that some Neanderthal groups used coloured pigments in symbolic ways – behaviour once regarded as the sole domain of our species.

“It’s really exciting. It adds a new facet to what we know about symbolic use of colour,” says Emma Pomeroy at the University of Cambridge, who wasn’t involved with the research.

The use of ochre – an iron-rich mineral with red, yellow or orange hues – has ancient roots, dating back at least 400,000 years in Europe and Africa. Bits of ochre are found at many Neanderthal sites, where they seem to have been used for practical purposes such as tanning clothing and as fire accelerants, as well as sometimes smeared on shell beads.

Neanderthals may have also used ochre to decorate their bodies, clothing and other surfaces, but such traces have long since disappeared. To investigate further, Francesco d’Errico at the University of Bordeaux, France, and his colleagues carried out a detailed analysis of ochre pieces found at Neanderthal sites in Crimea, Ukraine. By studying how ochre pieces were modified by Neanderthals, as well as performing a microscopic analysis of how they became worn down, the researchers could build a picture of how the objects were used.

The most compelling of these ochre objects was a yellow one that was at least 42,000 years old and had been ground and scraped into a crayon-like shape about 5 to 6 centimetres long. Detailed analysis shows that the tip had been worn down through use, then resharpened, indicating that it was reused over time as an implement to make marks.

“It was a tool that had been curated and reshaped several times, which makes it very special,” says d’Errico. “It’s not just a crayon by shape. It’s a crayon because it was used as a crayon. It’s something that may have been used on skin or a rock to make a line – the reflection, perhaps, of an artistic activity.”

The tip of an ochre fragment that has been used as a crayon and then resharpened d’Errico et al., Sci. Adv. 11, eadx4722

April Nowell at the University of Victoria in Canada, who wasn’t involved with the research, concurs. “You only maintain a point on a crayon if you want to make precise lines or designs,” she says.

The research team also identified another more ancient broken crayon, perhaps 70,000 years old, made from red ochre.

“It tells us so much just from those small bits of ochre,” says Pomeroy. “It’s that little bit of humanity that we can relate to. It really brings those individuals into touching distance.”

The Crimean crayon discoveries add to the small but growing body of evidence indicating the artistic talents of Neanderthals, such as 57,000-year-old finger carvings on a cave wall in France and mysterious circles crafted from stalagmites 175,000 years ago in another French cave.

They also lend weight to the idea that symbolic behaviour has very deep roots in our evolutionary past, rather than being a capacity that developed relatively recently only in Homo sapiens. “The underlying cognitive ability for symbolic behavior is undoubtedly shared by the last common ancestor of Homo sapiens, Denisovans and Neanderthals more than 700,000 years ago,” says Nowell.

Journal reference: Science Advances DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.adx4722
articles.reasoning: The discovery of prehistoric ochre crayons used by Neanderthals provides significant new evidence of symbolic and artistic behavior in ancient human relatives, deepening our understanding of human evolution and cognition. This finding has broad scientific and cultural significance, revealing a meaningful breakthrough in archaeology and anthropology with tangible insights into humanity's shared past.
articles.personality_title: Ancient crayons show Neanderthals made art 40,000 years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Neanderthals are ancient human relatives who lived tens of thousands of years ago. Scientists have long wondered if they used colors and symbols like modern humans do.

**What happened** – Researchers found ochre crayons in Crimea, a region in Ukraine, that are over 40,000 years old. These crayons were shaped and sharpened, showing signs they were used to draw lines on surfaces such as rocks or skin.

**Impact** – This discovery is strong proof that Neanderthals used colors for symbolic or artistic purposes, not just practical ones like tanning clothes. It changes how we understand their culture, showing they had skills similar to modern humans.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will continue studying ochre pieces from other sites and explore more evidence of Neanderthal art. This can help us learn more about how early humans and their relatives thought and expressed themselves.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The sharpened ochre crayons found in Crimea reveal that Neanderthals created art and used color in meaningful ways over 40,000 years ago.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des crayons préhistoriques montrent que les Néandertaliens faisaient de l'art il y a 40 000 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Néandertaliens sont des parents humains anciens qui ont vécu il y a des dizaines de milliers d'années. Les scientifiques se demandaient depuis longtemps s'ils utilisaient des couleurs et des symboles comme les humains modernes.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont trouvé des crayons d'ocre en Crimée, une région d'Ukraine, qui ont plus de 40 000 ans. Ces crayons ont été taillés et affûtés, montrant des signes qu'ils étaient utilisés pour dessiner des lignes sur des surfaces comme des roches ou la peau.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est une preuve forte que les Néandertaliens utilisaient les couleurs à des fins symboliques ou artistiques, pas seulement pratiques comme le tannage des vêtements. Cela change notre compréhension de leur culture, montrant qu'ils avaient des compétences proches des humains modernes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques continueront d'étudier des morceaux d'ocre d'autres sites et chercheront plus de preuves d'art néandertalien. Cela peut aider à mieux comprendre comment les premiers humains et leurs proches pensaient et s'exprimaient.

**Phrase clé** – Les crayons d'ocre taillés trouvés en Crimée révèlent que les Néandertaliens créaient de l'art et utilisaient la couleur de manière significative il y a plus de 40 000 ans.
articles.personality_title_es: Crayones antiguos muestran que los neandertales hacían arte hace 40,000 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los neandertales son parientes humanos antiguos que vivieron hace decenas de miles de años. Los científicos se han preguntado si usaban colores y símbolos como los humanos modernos.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores encontraron crayones de ocre en Crimea, una región de Ucrania, que tienen más de 40,000 años. Estos crayones fueron moldeados y afilados, mostrando señales de que se usaron para dibujar líneas en superficies como rocas o piel.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es una prueba fuerte de que los neandertales usaban colores con fines simbólicos o artísticos, no solo prácticos como para curtir ropa. Cambia nuestra visión de su cultura, mostrando que tenían habilidades similares a los humanos modernos.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando piezas de ocre de otros sitios y buscarán más evidencias del arte neandertal. Esto puede ayudar a entender mejor cómo pensaban y se expresaban los primeros humanos y sus parientes.

**Frase clave** – Los crayones de ocre afilados encontrados en Crimea revelan que los neandertales creaban arte y usaban color de manera significativa hace más de 40,000 años.

articles.title: Members of the European Parliament in Nova Gorica and Gorica explored the cross-border European Capital of Culture
articles.summary: The delegation of European parliamentarians visited Nova Gorica and Gorica, which this year form the first cross-border European Capital of Culture.
articles.content:
The delegation of European parliamentarians visited Nova Gorica and Gorica, which this year form the first cross-border European Capital of Culture.

Nova Gorica – A delegation of three members of the European Parliament’s Committee on Culture and Education visited Nova Gorica and Gorizia, which this year form the first cross-border European Capital of Culture (ECoC). The head of the delegation Hannes Heide emphasized at the end of the visit that ECoC Nova Gorica-Gorizia 2025 demonstrates how culture and cooperation can transcend borders and transform a shared history into common progress.

During the two-day visit, the Members of the European Parliament – in addition to Heide, Manuela Ripa and Joanna Scheuring-Wielgus, accompanied by Slovenian MEP Matjaž Nemec – listened to experts and local representatives from the fields of art, literature, cinematography, music, dance, cuisine, science, and theater to learn more about how the two cities, divided for decades, are coming together and presenting a model for Europe.

“I have been to many European Capitals of Culture. However, ECoC Nova Gorica-Gorizia 2025 is undoubtedly the most exceptional and incredible so far. Many people are truly dedicated to this project,” Heide said at the end of the visit. He highlighted that both Gorizias demonstrate that the values that unite us are much deeper than our divisions.

Nemec pointed out that GO! 2025 in Brussels is a success story. “It may be less felt in the local community, but the European Capital of Culture Nova Gorica-Gorizia is an example of an extremely good project with an absolutely exceptional message,” he noted.

The MEPs also met with political representatives from both countries, including the State Secretary at the Slovenian Ministry of Culture Marko Rusjan.

As reported by the ministry, Rusjan described the European Capital of Culture project as more than just a cultural event, as it has become a model of cooperation between two border cities and a symbol of overcoming borders. He added that the ECoC is not only the largest cultural event in the region’s history but also proof that culture connects and opens up space for cooperation in other areas as well.

The ECoC, which will feature over 400 events, will conclude with a closing event organized in Nova Gorica from December 1 to 5. (October 29)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the European Capital of Culture initiative uniting two border cities, Nova Gorica and Gorizia, fostering cross-border cooperation, cultural exchange, and reconciliation. This has broad societal significance as a model for overcoming historical divisions through culture, with substantial local and European impact. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful positive change.
articles.personality_title: Nova Gorica and Gorizia unite as first cross-border European Capital of Culture
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Nova Gorica in Slovenia and Gorizia in Italy are two cities that were separated by borders for many years. This year, they share the title of European Capital of Culture (ECoC), a special recognition given to cities that celebrate culture and creativity.

**What happened** – A group of European Parliament members visited Nova Gorica and Gorizia to see how these two cities are working together for the ECoC 2025 project. They talked to artists, musicians, writers, and local leaders to learn how culture is helping the cities connect after years apart.

**Impact** – This is the first time two cities from different countries share the European Capital of Culture title. It shows how culture can bring people together and help heal old divisions. The project includes more than 400 events and acts as a model for other border regions in Europe.

**What's next step** – The cultural celebrations will continue throughout the year, ending with a big closing event in Nova Gorica in early December. The success of this project could inspire similar cooperation between other cities divided by borders.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Nova Gorica and Gorizia’s shared cultural year proves that art and cooperation can unite communities across borders.

**Prochaine étape** – Les célébrations culturelles continueront toute l’année, avec un grand événement de clôture à Nova Gorica début décembre. Le succès de ce projet pourrait inspirer d’autres collaborations entre villes séparées par des frontières.

**En une phrase** – L’année culturelle commune de Nova Gorica et Gorizia prouve que l’art et la coopération peuvent unir des communautés au-delà des frontières.

articles.title: Portugal guarantees that it will use the entirety of the PRR subsidies
articles.summary: The Portuguese PRR has a value of 22.2 billion euros
articles.content:
The Minister of Economy and Territorial Cohesion, Manuel Castro Almeida, assured today that the country will “utilize the entirety of the subsidies from the Recovery and Resilience Plan (PRR).”

In an intervention during the general debate on the State Budget proposal for 2026 (OE2026), the minister indicated that the Government aims for the economy to grow to the average of the European Union, with one of the strategic pillars being the “economic and social profitability of European Funds.”

In this regard, he assured that the “entirety of the PRR subsidies” will be invested, also pointing out that it is within the expected deadlines.

“The 7th payment request has already been received in its entirety and the 8th request will be submitted this year, within the set deadline,” he said, so “it is not worth the prophets of doom insisting on prophecies of failure.”

For the goal of economic growth, the five strategic pillars listed by the minister also include encouraging private investment, strengthening public investment, betting on innovation, and increasing exports.

The minister also emphasized that in the reprogramming of the PRR, a “Financial Instrument for Innovation and Competitiveness” was created, to which allocations from the PRR that cannot be executed within the expected deadlines are being transferred.

“In this way, we correct an original sin of the PRR that allocated much less funding for companies,” he said.

In total, the Portuguese PRR has a value of 22.2 billion euros, with 16.3 billion euros in subsidies and 5.9 billion euros in loans from the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism.
articles.reasoning: The article reports that Portugal is committed to fully utilizing a significant 22.2 billion euro Recovery and Resilience Plan (PRR) subsidy, aiming for broad economic growth and innovation. This has a meaningful positive impact on the country's economy and society, with clear strategic pillars and corrective measures to enhance competitiveness. The story focuses on a concrete policy action with substantial scope and detailed context.
articles.personality_title: Portugal commits to fully using €22.2 billion Recovery Plan to boost economy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Portugal is receiving funds through the Recovery and Resilience Plan (PRR), a program designed to help countries recover from economic challenges and invest in growth.

**What happened** – Manuel Castro Almeida, Portugal’s Minister of Economy and Territorial Cohesion, announced that the country will use all the subsidies from the PRR. He confirmed that payments are on schedule, with the seventh payment already received and the eighth planned for this year.

**Impact** – This commitment means Portugal will invest €22.2 billion to support economic growth, innovation, and competitiveness. The government aims to raise the economy to match the average level of the European Union by focusing on five key areas: using European funds wisely, encouraging private investment, strengthening public investment, promoting innovation, and increasing exports. A new financial tool was also created to help companies benefit more from the funds.

**What's next step** – Portugal will continue submitting payment requests and investing the funds as planned. The newly created Financial Instrument for Innovation and Competitiveness will help redirect unused funds to support businesses, improving the overall effectiveness of the plan.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Portugal is dedicated to fully using its €22.2 billion Recovery and Resilience Plan funding to strengthen its economy through innovation and investment.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Portugal s’engage à utiliser intégralement les 22,2 milliards d’euros du plan de relance
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Portugal reçoit des fonds dans le cadre du Plan de relance et de résilience (PRR), un programme destiné à aider les pays à se remettre des difficultés économiques et à investir dans la croissance.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Manuel Castro Almeida, ministre de l’Économie et de la Cohésion territoriale du Portugal, a annoncé que le pays utilisera toutes les subventions du PRR. Il a confirmé que les paiements sont dans les délais, la septième tranche ayant déjà été reçue et la huitième prévue cette année.

**Impact** – Cet engagement signifie que le Portugal investira 22,2 milliards d’euros pour soutenir la croissance économique, l’innovation et la compétitivité. Le gouvernement vise à faire passer l’économie au niveau moyen de l’Union européenne en se concentrant sur cinq domaines clés : une utilisation efficace des fonds européens, l’encouragement de l’investissement privé, le renforcement de l’investissement public, la promotion de l’innovation et l’augmentation des exportations. Un nouvel outil financier a également été créé pour aider davantage les entreprises.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Portugal continuera à soumettre ses demandes de paiement et à investir les fonds comme prévu. L’Instrument financier pour l’innovation et la compétitivité aidera à réorienter les fonds non utilisés pour soutenir les entreprises, améliorant ainsi l’efficacité globale du plan.

**Une phrase clé** – Le Portugal s’engage à utiliser intégralement les 22,2 milliards d’euros de son plan de relance pour renforcer son économie grâce à l’innovation et à l’investissement.
articles.personality_title_es: Portugal se compromete a usar completamente los 22.2 mil millones de euros del plan de recuperación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Portugal recibe fondos a través del Plan de Recuperación y Resiliencia (PRR), un programa creado para ayudar a los países a recuperarse de dificultades económicas e invertir en crecimiento.

**Qué pasó** – Manuel Castro Almeida, ministro de Economía y Cohesión Territorial de Portugal, anunció que el país usará todas las subvenciones del PRR. Confirmó que los pagos van según lo previsto, con el séptimo ya recibido y el octavo planeado para este año.

**Impacto** – Este compromiso significa que Portugal invertirá 22.2 mil millones de euros para apoyar el crecimiento económico, la innovación y la competitividad. El gobierno busca que la economía alcance el promedio de la Unión Europea enfocándose en cinco áreas clave: usar bien los fondos europeos, fomentar la inversión privada, fortalecer la inversión pública, promover la innovación y aumentar las exportaciones. También se creó una nueva herramienta financiera para ayudar más a las empresas.

**Próximo paso** – Portugal seguirá presentando solicitudes de pago e invirtiendo los fondos según lo planeado. El nuevo Instrumento Financiero para Innovación y Competitividad ayudará a redirigir fondos no usados para apoyar a las empresas, mejorando la efectividad del plan.

**Una frase clave** – Portugal está comprometido a usar completamente los 22.2 mil millones de euros del Plan de Recuperación para fortalecer su economía con innovación e inversión.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a large, sturdy golden bridge made of interlocking euro coins spanning a vibrant Portuguese landscape with rolling hills and a calm river below, symbolizing the full and timely investment of Recovery and Resilience Plan funds, while beams of light shaped like upward arrows gently illuminate the bridge, representing economic growth, innovation, and strengthened public and private investment.
